awd_titl_txt: Investigating the Formation of Engineers and the Future Professoriate: Linking Writing Approaches and Attitudes to Doctoral Socialization, Persistence, and Attrition
awd_abstract_narration:
Though doctoral engineering education is understudied as a whole, attrition in graduate engineering education is particularly unexplored. Recent reports by the Council of Graduate Schools reported that in engineering, the 10-year completion rate for doctoral programs for domestic students was only 59%. Attrition is problematic for several reasons. First, since many domestic students are funded by federal grants (through NSF, for example) and through domestic industry, each domestic student that leaves academia prematurely represents a lost investment. Second, graduate students are required for the continued quantity and quality of engineering research and development that supports all facets of engineering, impacting defense, biomedical applications, and energy technologies, and will be future thought-leaders in engineering industry and academic research. Even though engineering is usually represented solely as a mathematical and scientific discipline, being able to successfully write for an academic engineering audience can be the difference between completing a Ph.D. or leaving without a degree.  However, to date, no research has studied the linkage between engineering writing, attrition/persistence and career goals for engineering graduate students.  This study employs both qualitative interview techniques and statistical methods to study domestic graduate students who have decided to stay in graduate school and those that decided to leave academia. 

According to Academic Literacies Theory, Role Identity Theory, and Vygotskian Sociocultural Theory applied to graduate students and academic writing, the ability to communicate as a member of a discipline (i.e., develop disciplinary discourse) is critical to the development of disciplinary identity and feelings of belonging to a research community. Other studies have linked these characteristics to persistence in graduate school; however, no work to date explores student attitudes and concepts of writing in engineering as it relates to attrition, persistence, and goals of careers in academia for graduate students. An exploratory embedded mixed methods approach with a qualitative emphasis is being conducted over the three years of this grant. This research design seeks to examine the writing approaches and attitudes of graduate students in graduate programs and in students who decided to leave academia before completing their graduate studies (non-completers). With the broader purpose of forming competencies and identities for future domestic faculty from graduate students, the guiding research questions for this study are as follows: (1) How do graduate students at various stages in their Ph.D. programs in engineering perceive the role of academic writing as it relates to academic persistence and the desire to pursue academic careers? (2) How are these perceptions different or similar for graduate students who are considering leaving or have left their Ph.D. programs before graduating? (3) Can writing concepts, attitudes, and self-efficacies (measured through survey constructs) predict or correlate strongly with graduate engineering students' attrition or persistence?  The intellectual merit of this work lies in the fundamental advancement of theories of engineering formation and socialization at the doctoral level, which to date are underexplored. Furthermore, the role that writing plays in the socialization process, including its potential relationship with the decision to leave academia has not been explored in a rigorous quantitative way in any discipline. As the broader impacts of the study, the findings of the study will facilitate the development of writing based interventions to increase the persistence of U.S. doctoral engineering students. Broader impacts activities include dissemination of research results via academic courses for graduate students, and workshops, webinars, and resources for graduate students and faculty.

por.por_cntn:
The objective of this study was to investigate the linkage between engineering writing and disciplinary discourse with other mechanisms of engineering graduate socialization, such as identity formation, socialization, persistence, and desire to pursue academic careers.  These processes in engineering graduate students are often invisible but are important to retaining diverse and competent future thought leaders to become professors and engineering industry.   There were two phases of the project to capture interviews and surveys. The first phase focused on data collection from current graduate engineering students who would likely persist in their PhD programs, and the second phase investigated  graduate engineering students who were questioning leaving their PhD programs or who had already left the engineering PhD. We used quantitative survey methods and qualitative interview methods to answer research questions related to career trajectory and connections with aspects of attrition and persistence with writing tasks.

This research resulted in several important findings that have been published or are in the process of being published in peer-reviewed conference papers and journal publications. First, writing attitudes correlate in statistically significant ways with intended career trajectories, such that students with weaker writing attitudes are more likely to pursue non-research careers in industry, whereas students with stronger writing attitudes consider a wider breadth of careers. This finding has implications for writing as a platform to broaden participation across engineering career sectors. Second, the socialization experiences of graduate students, including opportunities to write and participate in authentic disciplinary activities, all of which are mediated by the advisor, are crucial to success in graduate school. The findings from this study are some of the first to characterize critical events that can cause engineering graduate students to consider attrition. While there are a variety of factors that influence attrition and persistence decisions, literature to date had not captured the mechanisms by which students begin to consider leaving.  Within these attrition decision discussions, we found that engineering doctoral students struggle with the gatekeeping role that engineering advisors have as a conduit of opportunities to publish, attend conferences, or thrive in graduate school, in spite of student attempts to take agentic actions to facilitate their own success. Our research shows that in engineering disciplines, the relationship with the doctoral advisor is highly one-directional, with the PhD student being nearly fully reliant on the resources that an advisor can provide as a gatekeeper. While prior research discusses the nature of this misalignment in terms of a power dynamic, which is not untrue, our research shows how even non-malicious advisors serve as gatekeepers more than they may think, in ways that impact engineering thriving. 

This work is impactful in at least four ways. First, this was the first study to incorporate specific conversations about academic writing within engineering doctoral socialization, a topic not considered a focus of research to date.  Second, findings from both the quantitative and qualitive phases of this grant highlight the complex relationship between psychological and sociological elements required for engineering graduate students to thrive in graduate school, calling attention to writing as a vehicle toward thriving.  Third, findings from this work have been published in cross disciplinary conferences that reach technical writing and communications audiences, which typically do not have deep disciplinary knowledge, thereby providing important research-to-practice mechanisms for populations who interface with engineering students as writers. Last, while significant research questions were answered through this grant, we also highlighted important areas for future research that can help to retain PhD students to become future thought leaders in academia and industry.  In sum, this research has contributed to research and theory that will be foundational for engineering education and higher education literature, and motivates new research directions focused on both engineering writing and its role in facilitating the ability to thrive in academic engineering.

The broader impacts of this grant are related to broadening participation in academic engineering, particularly for graduate students who may pursue the professoriate.  Specific broader impacts activities that have resulted from this grant include 12 workshops and seminars conducted locally, nationally, and internationally to graduate-level STEM students.  The findings from this study are incorporated in a graduate level Mechanical Engineering academic writing course that is taught annually which has impacted at least 140 graduate students in engineering and science at Penn State University. Writing survey instruments, publications, and resources developed and employed through this grant are distributed via scholarship and are hosted on the PIs research website.
